growing.water: Low to moderate; drought tolerant once established
growing.soil: Prefers well-draining soil; tolerates poor, rocky soils

planting.whenToPlant: Sow seeds in spring or fall; seeds need light to germinate so surface sow
planting.propagation: Primarily by seed; can self-seed readily
planting.depth: Surface sow, do not cover seeds
companion: Comfrey (both benefit from similar growing conditions)

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Remove spent flower stalks to prevent unwanted self-seeding
careAndMaintenance.stakingOrSupport: Usually not needed; tall flower stalks may benefit from staking in windy areas
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: Perennial in warmer zones; biennial in colder zones, often self-seeds to maintain presence

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Harvest leaves before flowering for medicinal use; flower tops collected when in bloom
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pick mature leaves and flowers during dry weather; leaves can be harvested multiple times
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Air dry leaves and flowers in a shaded, well-ventilated area; store in airtight containers
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Non-toxic; leaves are edible when cooked but are very hairy and can irritate the throat if eaten raw
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Leaves are generally not used due to texture but young leaves can be cooked like spinach

medicinal.Respiratory Support: Traditionally used as a remedy for coughs, bronchitis, and congestion. Leaves and flowers are used in teas, tinctures, or infused oils to soothe the respiratory tract and reduce inflammation.
medicinal.Anti-inflammatory: Applied topically in infused oils or salves to soothe skin irritations, burns, wounds, and hemorrhoids due to its anti-inflammatory and demulcent properties.
medicinal.Ear Infections: Infused oils of mullein flowers are sometimes used as ear drops for earache relief.
medicinal.Diuretic: Has mild diuretic properties, supporting kidney health and detoxification.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Mild, slightly herbal scent; not strongly aromatic but pleasant when dried

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Generally avoided by deer and rabbits due to leaf texture

funFacts: Mullein's tall flower spikes make it a striking garden plant and important nectar source.
The dense, woolly leaves were historically used as makeshift bandages or candle wicks.
